Not like *every single* headline or research publication... but an overwhelmingly significant chunk of them.
@gacossey Maybe my mind tends to fixate more on negative news, so that could be why I *feel* like it's much more often negative than positive... but I'd really like to see more uplifting headlines...

I feel like any time I see new research mentioning my condition, it adds to the feeling of hopelessness (e.g., shortened lifespan; increased dementia risk; more comorbidities) rather than hope (e.g., new treatment approaches).

Someone should study the impact of overwhelmingly negative news (e.g., "Early-onset dementia was a particular risk for those with a psychiatric diagnosis.") on the mental health of ppl w/ mental illness... Being bombarded w/ bad news really takes a toll. https://t.co/kSpsuDrvRp https://t.co/RxY2iyMTQQ

@drlindanp @DrMarinaHarris #Selfcare is important! ‚ù§Ô∏è 

However, it's frustrating to see workplaces fail to acknowledge their role in causing #burnout. Self-care alone can't undo the stress of 80-hr workweeks. Suggesting self-care w/o addressing the source can seem like putting a bandaid on a bullet wound.
@ac_robers @BobsBurgersFOX Congratulations!!! Also, that is so creative!

@DrMarinaHarris If a ton of ppl in a field are experiencing burnout, that's not an individual issue; it's a systemic issue (e.g., overworked). The solution should address the source of burnout. The self-care "solution" places the blame on individuals ("just try harder") rather than the source.
RT @DrMarinaHarris: Prescribing "self-care" for burnout is victim blaming. Full stop.
